|06:08|![](https://avatars.slack-edge.com/2018-04-27/354445776386_e258f5ed5ba887b08668_72.jpg)|shinyu|<https://github.com/vivliostyle/community/discussions/140><br><blockquote>I previously opened an issue <https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle.js/issues/1155|(#1155)> in this repository to seek initial guidance for integrating Vivliostyle into my project. Unfortunately, I never had the chance to follow through on that task until now.<br><br>Here is the original context of that issue for reference:<br><br>> _Hello ğŸ™‚,_<br>> <br>> _I am working on a NestJS API project that receives an HTML template and generates a PDF file from a page opened via Chrome Headless using Puppeteer. I previously used Paged.js, which provides a JavaScript polyfill that I integrate into the HTML template in the Chrome page. Now, I would like to create a second route that supports the Paged Media specification but uses Vivliostyle instead._<br>> <br>> _I have installed the "@vivliostyle/core" dependency via npm, but I am having trouble integrating Vivliostyle with Puppeteer in my project._<br>> <br>> _Thank you in advance for your assistance ğŸ™‚_<br><br>Initially, I had postponed the migration to Vivliostyle because some features required for my project were missing, particularly those related to table rendering. However, I noticed that recent updates to Vivliostyle have addressed the issues I identified. Specifically:<br><br>â€¢ The release of version <https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle.js/releases/tag/v2.31.2|v2.31.2> included several fixes that resolved critical problems.<br>â€¢ The merge of <https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle.js/pull/1476|PR #1476> further improved table support and addressed key limitations.<br><br>In the previous issue, I received the following recommendation (<https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle.js/issues/1155#issuecomment-1493864319|vivliostyle/vivliostyle.js#1155 (comment)>):<br><br>> _I recommend you to use Vivliostyle CLI._  <br>> _<https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle-cli|https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle-cli>_  <br>> _Vivliostyle CLI uses Playwright (switched from Puppeteer last year)._<br><br>However, I would prefer not to use `vivliostyle/cli` for the following reasons:<br><br>â€¢ I want to avoid writing and reading from disk for every request. Managing temporary HTML and PDF files on the disk (writing the HTML received in the HTTP request, passing the temporary file path to the CLI, and then writing the PDF to disk to delete it afterward) seems overly complex. Instead, I prefer handling everything in memory (RAM) using buffers<br>â€¢ I need to have control over several security parameters for the headless browser and the ability to filter incoming and outgoing network requests. These customizations are important in my use case, and using the CLI would limit this level of control.<br><br>### Current Progress and Challenges<br><br>Initially, we used PagedJS as a JavaScript polyfill for PDF generation. The process was as follows:<br><br>1. Launch a new page in a headless browser.<br>2. Inject the received HTML into the page.<br>3. Add the JavaScript polyfill to the page.<br>4. Use the `pdf` function from the Puppeteer/Playwright API.<br><br>We decided to transition to Vivliostyle for a new HTTP endpoint and opted to use `@vivliostyle/core` instead of the `vivliostyle/cli` for technical reasons. However, I have encountered challenges when trying to integrate it into our workflow.<br><br>To start, I created a TypeScript script to declare the Vivliostyle module globally on the `window` object:<br><br>import * as Vivliostyle from "@vivliostyle/core";<br><br>declare global {<br>    interface Window {<br>        Vivliostyle: typeof Vivliostyle;<br>    }<br>}<br><br>window.Vivliostyle = Vivliostyle;<br><br>I then bundled and minified this script to embed it into the page where the received HTML is loaded.<br><br>The main issue arises with the `printHTML` function, which prepares the document with the polyfill before opening the print modal. Here's the implementation I am working with:<br><br>private async setupVivliostyleAndPrint(page: Page, templateHtml: string): Promise<void> {<br>    await this.addVivliostyleScriptsToPage(page);<br><br>    await page.evaluate((html) => {<br>        return new Promise<void>((resolve, reject) => {<br>            const config: VivliostylePrintConfig = {<br>                title: 'PDF Generation',<br>                printCallback: (iframeWin) => {<br>                    iframeWin.print();<br>                    resolve();<br>                },<br>                errorCallback: (message) => {<br>                    reject(new Error(message));<br>                },<br>                hideIframe: true,<br>                removeIframe: true<br>            };<br><br>            window.Vivliostyle.printHTML(html, config);<br>        });<br>    }, templateHtml);<br>}<br><br>### Request for Guidance<br><br>I would greatly appreciate any guidance or recommendations on:<br><br>â€¢ Properly leveraging the `@vivliostyle/core` module for my use case.<br>â€¢ Best practices for embedding and using the `printHTML` function effectively.<br>â€¢ Any potential pitfalls or alternative approaches I should consider.<br><br>Thank you in advance for your time and support!</blockquote>|
|06:15|![](https://avatars.slack-edge.com/2018-04-27/354445776386_e258f5ed5ba887b08668_72.jpg)|shinyu|<https://github.com/vivliostyle/vivliostyle-cli/discussions/558><br><blockquote>Hello, I'm using Vivliostyle's JavaScript API to convert dynamic markdown (generated from a database) to PDF. Based on my understanding, the process requires saving both the markdown data and config to temporary files before passing them to the `build` function.<br><br>Hereâ€™s my current workflow:<br><br>1. Generate markdown strings from database data<br>2. Split the markdown by page and save to temporary files<br>3. Create a config JSON object and save it as a temporary file (with `entry` pointing to the markdown files)<br>4. Call the `build` function with the config path<br>5. Poll for PDF generation completion using `setTimeout`<br>6. Clean up temporary files<br><br>My questions:<br><br>1. Is it possible to pass markdown data directly to the `build` function without saving to temporary files?<br>2. Can the config be passed directly (without saving as a temporary file)?<br>3. Is there a way to detect PDF generation completion without polling?<br><br>Thanks in advance!</blockquote>|
